Summary: The proposal aims to integrate causal reasoning into neural networks by combining graph-based causal representations with neural architectures. It hypothesizes that explicit modeling of causal structures and intervention-aware training can improve out-of-distribution generalization and counterfactual reasoning. The method involves causal graph integration, intervention-based training, and scalable causal discovery, with experiments planned on synthetic and real-world datasets.
Strengths: Clear problem statement highlighting the limitations of current deep learning models in causal reasoning.
Well-grounded motivation and hypothesis, supported by recent literature.
Innovative proposed method combining graph neural networks and causal discovery.
Comprehensive experiment plan covering validation, OOD generalization, counterfactual reasoning, scalability, and ablation studies.
Weaknesses: Lacks detailed discussion on potential technical challenges, such as computational complexity or feasibility of generating interventional data.
Baseline comparisons could be more explicitly justified to ensure fairness.
Limited discussion on the scalability of the proposed method in real-world high-dimensional settings.
Questions: How will the proposed method handle the computational complexity of integrating causal discovery into neural networks?
What are the specific challenges in generating realistic interventional data, and how will they be addressed?
How will the fairness of baseline comparisons be ensured, particularly in high-dimensional settings?
What specific techniques will be used to ensure interpretability in high-dimensional data?
What are the expected computational costs of the proposed method?
Limitations: Potential computational complexity of integrating causal discovery into neural networks.
Feasibility of generating realistic interventional data for training.
Scalability of the method in real-world high-dimensional datasets.
Generalizability of the learned causal graphs across diverse domains.
